user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl:
```c
void OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;
    int                             os_flags;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    os_flags = fcntl(impl->fd, F_GETFL);
    if (os_flags == -1)
    {
        /* No recourse if F_GETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
        OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_GETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    else
    {
        os_flags |= OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS;
        if (fcntl(impl->fd, F_SETFL, os_flags) == -1)
        {
            /* No recourse if F_SETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
            OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_SETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
        }
    }

    impl->selectable = true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other fragments in the function do not appear to violate Rule 8.13: the function parameter is already a pointer to a const-qualified type (const OS_object_token_t *token), the local pointer variable declaration (OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl) is used to modify the underlying object (impl->selectable = true) so it legitimately points to a non-const type, and the uses of fcntl/strerror and the os_flags variable do not involve pointers that could/should be const-qualified. The only places where const-qualification could be lost or questioned are the macro definition (it takes tok and takes its address via &(tok)) and the call site that passes *token into that macro; these need inspection to ensure no const qualifier is being discarded.
